abstract.p: Shares of Rolls-Royce PLC plummet more than 20 percent after company backs away from promises of double-digit growth next year; reports 93.5 percent decline in first-half net income to 8 million pounds, or $11.8 million, from 123 million pounds a year ago; photo (S)

block.p: The shares in the world's second-biggest aircraft engine maker, Rolls-Royce P.L.C., plummeted more than 20 percent after the company backed away from promises of double-digit growth next year. The fall was the biggest one-day decline since the stock began trading in 1988. Rolls-Royce, whose customers include Airbus Industrie and Boeing, set off the fall by saying its earnings would be flat through 2001. It reported a 93.5 percent fall in its first-half net income, to $:8 million, or $11.8 million, from $:123 million a year ago. John Rose, the company's chief executive, said he expected the setback in earnings growth to be a one-time event.
